common: Data are not available on use in pregnant women to evaluate for drug-associated risks of major birth defects, miscarriage, or adverse maternal or fetal outcomes
Clinicians are encouraged to register patients in the Dayvigo pregnancy registry by calling 1-888-274-2378

description: Lemborexant caused maternal toxicity that consisted of decreased body weight and food consumption and toxicity to offspring consisting of decreased pup body weights, decreased femur length, and decreased acoustic startle responses at 206 times the MRHD based on AUC

common: Available data from a lactation study in 8 women indicates that the drug is transferred into the breastmilk of nursing mothers; results have established a mean daily infant dose of 0.0029 mg/kg/day and a relative infant dose of less than 2% of the maternal dose; These data support that transfer of this drug into breastmilk is low
There are no data on effects of this drug on breastfed infant, or effects on milk production; monitor infants exposed through breastmilk for excessive sedation

Consider the developmental and health benefits of breastfeeding along with the mother’s clinical need for the drug and any potential adverse effects on the breastfed infant from the drug or from the underlying maternal condition

description: CNS depressant that can impair daytime wakefulness even when used as prescribed
CNS depression may persist and affect next-day tasks (eg, driving ability)
CNS depression may persist in some patients for several days after discontinuing
Coadministration with other CNS depressants may increase risk

specific.type: Sleep paralysis, hypnagogic/hypnopompic hallucinations, cataplexy-like symptoms
description: Sleep paralysis, an inability to move or speak for up to several minutes during sleep-wake transitions, and hypnagogic/hypnopompic hallucinations, including vivid and disturbing perceptions, can occur
Mild cataplexy can occur, with symptoms that include periods of leg weakness lasting from seconds to a few minutes

Complex sleep behaviors, including sleepwalking, sleep-driving, and engaging in other activities while not fully awake (eg, preparing and eating food, making phone calls, having sex), reported with hypnotic use
Events can occur in hypnotic-naïve as well as in hypnotic-experienced persons
Patients usually do not remember these events
Complex sleep behaviors may occur following the first or any subsequent use of lemborexant, with or without concomitant use of alcohol and other CNS depressants
Discontinue immediately if patient experiences a complex sleep behavior
Studied in mild to severe obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and moderate-to-severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) in short-term clinical trials

Studies have shown that clinically meaningful respiratory effects in patients with compromised respiratory function cannot be excluded; consider effect on respiratory function if prescribed to patients with compromised respiratory function; not studied in COPD patients with FEV1 <30% predicted
In primarily depressed patients treated with hypnotics, worsening of depression and suicidal thoughts and actions (including completed suicides) have been reported
Monitor for new behavioral signs or symptoms
Evaluate for comorbid diagnoses where insomnia may be presenting manifestation of a medial and/or psychiatric disorder
Failure of insomnia to remit after 7-10 days of treatment may indicate presence of a primary psychiatric and/or medical illness that should be evaluated
Worsening of insomnia or emergence of new cognitive or behavioral abnormalities may be result of an unrecognized underlying psychiatric or medical disorder
CNS depressants
Avoid coadministration
Coadministration with other CNS depressants (eg, benzodiazepines, opioids, tricyclic antidepressants, alcohol) increases the risk of CNS depression, which can cause daytime impairment

Coadministration with alcohol increases lemborexant peak plasma concentration and AUC and produced a numerically greater negative impact on postural stability and memory as compared with alcohol alone
Strong or moderate CYP3A inhibitors
Avoid coadministration
Coadministration with a strong or moderate CYP3A inhibitor increases lemborexant AUC and peak plasma concentration which may increase the risk of lemborexant adverse reactions
Weak CYP3A inhibitors
Modify lemborexant dose
Do not exceed 5 mg/night if coadministered with weak CYP3A inhibitors (eg, chlorzoxazone, ranitidine)
CYP3A inducers
Avoid coadministration
Concomitant use with a strong or moderate CYP3A inducer decreases lemborexant exposure, which may reduce lemborexant efficacy
CYP2B6 substrates
Consider increasing CYP2B6 substrate dose as recommended in prescribing information
Coadministration decreases AUC of CYP2B6 substrates
Check prescribing information for CYP2B6 substrate for dosage recommendations if coadministered

Lower nightly dose of lemborexant recommended if coadministered with weak CYP3A4 inhibitors. See drug monograph for specific dosage modification.

lemborexant will decrease the level or effect of velpatasvir by  affecting hepatic enzyme CYP2B6 metabolism. Modify Therapy/Monitor Closely. Monitor CYP2B6 substrate for adequate clinical response. Consider increasing the CYP2B6 substrate dose according to specific prescribing recommendations.
